text: When staying busy doing personal portfolio work/ continuing github commits, will it be important to continue with Java/JavaScript as far as what apprenticeships are looking for?  Is there certain languages LaunchCode partners use primarily or is it pretty varied? I'm assuming we learned the techstack we did as it'll be more prevalent? After passing demo, even if 3/5 -> can you continue work on project to increase that score by march 6th (even if independently) as you can with the other categories (interview and resume)?

elements.text: When staying busy doing personal portfolio work/ continuing github commits, will it be important to continue with Java/JavaScript as far as what apprenticeships are looking for?  Is there certain languages LaunchCode partners use primarily or is it pretty varied? I'm assuming we learned the techstack we did as it'll be more prevalent? After passing demo, even if 3/5 -> can you continue work on project to increase that score by march 6th (even if independently) as you can with the other categories (interview and resume)?

text: JavaScript and Java are ubiquitous languages that will always be useful; React is used everywhere as well. That being said, there are a very wide variety of roles that use different languages and draw on different skills, so oftentimes the best advice I can give is to pursue languages or projects that capture your interests. It is far, far more important to be consistent in learning _any_ technology than to be inconsistent in learning the "best" technologies.

text: As for the demo question, that's something that we will get answered during class on Thursday.
